texts.orig: Q.3 How long can I remain outside the United States with my Permanent Resident Card (green card)?
texts.text: Q.3 How long can I remain outside the United States with my Permanent Resident Card (green card)?

texts.label: text
texts.orig: You will maintain status provided you do not remain outside the United States for longer than one year and you maintain a bona fide domicile in the United States. Failure to return to the United States within one year may jeopardize permanent resident status. If you are in possession of a valid re-entry permit issued by the USCIS, you must return to the United

texts.orig: Q.4 What if I have been outside the United States for longer than twelve months?
texts.text: Q.4 What if I have been outside the United States for longer than twelve months?

texts.orig: If you are not in possession of a valid re-entry permit, or your re-entry permit has expired, you will require a new immigrant visa to re-enter the United States to resume your residence there.

texts.text: Q.6 I have lost my Permanent Resident Card (green card). What do I do?

texts.label: text
texts.orig: If you have been outside the United States for less than twelve months, you should contact the immigrant visa section at the Embassy http://lebanon.usembassy.gov/immigrant_visas.html.  If you have been outside for longer than twelve months and you wish to return to resume permanent residence, you will require a new immigrant visa.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Q.7 I am a Lawful Permanent Resident of the United States. I have recently given birth to a child. What type of visa does he/she require to return with me to the United States?
texts.text: Q.7 I am a Lawful Permanent Resident of the United States. I have recently given birth to a child. What type of visa does he/she require to return with me to the United States?

texts.label: text
texts.orig: You will not require a visa for your child if: he/she is under two years of age; it is his/her first entry into the United States since birth; and he/she is being accompanied by the parent who is applying for readmission as a permanent resident upon the parent's first return to the United States after the child's birth. Your child will require his or her own passport, if not included on the accompanying parent's passport, and his/her long form birth certificate, listing both parents' names. In the event that one parent is a citizen of the United States, the child may have a claim to U.S. citizenship. If you believe this is the case for your child, you may contact the Embassy's American Citizen Services section at BeirutACS@state.gov.
texts.text: You will not require a visa for your child if: he/she is under two years of age; it is his/her first entry into the United States since birth; and he/she is being accompanied by the parent who is applying for readmission as a permanent resident upon the parent's first return to the United States after the child's birth. Your child will require his or her own passport, if not included on the accompanying parent's passport, and his/her long form birth certificate, listing both parents' names. In the event that one parent is a citizen of the United States, the child may have a claim to U.S. citizenship. If you believe this is the case for your child, you may contact the Embassy's American Citizen Services section at BeirutACS@state.gov.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Q.8 I have a green card, but I am only going back to the United States for a short visit. What do I do?
texts.text: Q.8 I have a green card, but I am only going back to the United States for a short visit. What do I do?

texts.label: text
texts.orig: If you are a Lawful Permanent Resident (green card holder) and you have been outside the United States for longer than twelve months, or two years if you have a re-entry permit, you will be required to either apply for a visitor visa, or if eligible, travel visa free under the Visa Waiver Program.
texts.text: If you are a Lawful Permanent Resident (green card holder) and you have been outside the United States for longer than twelve months, or two years if you have a re-entry permit, you will be required to either apply for a visitor visa, or if eligible, travel visa free under the Visa Waiver Program.

texts.label: text

texts.orig: Q.9 I have a Permanent Resident Card (green card) and I no longer wish to live in the United States. What do I do?
texts.text: Q.9 I have a Permanent Resident Card (green card) and I no longer wish to live in the United States. What do I do?

texts.label: text
texts.orig: If you no longer wish to reside in the United States, you may formally abandon your status by completing the form I-407 (http://photos.state.gov/libraries/164203/dhs/I-407.pdf.)
texts.text: If you no longer wish to reside in the United States, you may formally abandon your status by completing the form I-407 (http://photos.state.gov/libraries/164203/dhs/I-407.pdf.)

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Q.1 What is the difference between the KI visa for fiancé(e)s and the K-3 visa for spouses?
texts.text: Q.1 What is the difference between the KI visa for fiancé(e)s and the K-3 visa for spouses?

texts.label: text
texts.orig: The KI visa is issued to the fiancé(e) of a U.S. citizen who will marry in the United States and apply to take up permanent residence after marriage. The K-3 and K-4 visa is issued to the spouse of a U.S. citizen who is the beneficiary of an immediate relative petition and his or her child(ren) under the age of 21. The K-3 and K-4 visa allows the holder to travel to the United States to reside while his or her immigrant visa petition is being processed by the U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Services and to apply for an immigrant visa once the petition has been approved.
texts.text: The KI visa is issued to the fiancé(e) of a U.S. citizen who will marry in the United States and apply to take up permanent residence after marriage. The K-3 and K-4 visa is issued to the spouse of a U.S. citizen who is the beneficiary of an immediate relative petition and his or her child(ren) under the age of 21. The K-3 and K-4 visa allows the holder to travel to the United States to reside while his or her immigrant visa petition is being processed by the U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Services and to apply for an immigrant visa once the petition has been approved.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: back to top
texts.text: back to top

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Q.2 If the immigrant visa interview has been scheduled, does this mean I cannot apply for the K-3 or K-4 visa?
texts.text: Q.2 If the immigrant visa interview has been scheduled, does this mean I cannot apply for the K-3 or K-4 visa?

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Yes. If you have been scheduled for an immigrant visa interview, or indeed if the Embassy or National Visa Center has received the approved petition, but not yet scheduled the immigrant visa interview, you are not eligible to apply for a K-3 or K-4 visa. You are required to pursue your application for an immigrant visa.
texts.text: Yes. If you have been scheduled for an immigrant visa interview, or indeed if the Embassy or National Visa Center has received the approved petition, but not yet scheduled the immigrant visa interview, you are not eligible to apply for a K-3 or K-4 visa. You are required to pursue your application for an immigrant visa.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: back to top
texts.text: back to top

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Q.3 If I have been refused an immigrant visa, can I apply for a K-3 or K-4 visa?
texts.text: Q.3 If I have been refused an immigrant visa, can I apply for a K-3 or K-4 visa?

texts.label: text
texts.orig: No. If you have applied for an immigrant visa and have been refused, you are not eligible to apply for the K visa.
texts.text: No. If you have applied for an immigrant visa and have been refused, you are not eligible to apply for the K visa.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: back to top
texts.text: back to top

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Q.4 If I have been refused an immigrant visa, but my child has yet to apply for the visa, can he or she apply for the K-4 visa?
texts.text: Q.4 If I have been refused an immigrant visa, but my child has yet to apply for the visa, can he or she apply for the K-4 visa?

texts.label: text
texts.orig: No. If you have been refused an immigrant visa, your child is, unfortunately, not eligible to apply for the K-4 visa, even if he or she has yet to apply for an immigrant visa.
texts.text: No. If you have been refused an immigrant visa, your child is, unfortunately, not eligible to apply for the K-4 visa, even if he or she has yet to apply for an immigrant visa.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: back to top
texts.text: back to top

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Q.5 Can I apply for a K-3 or K-4 visa if I no longer wish to continue with my application for an immigrant visa?
texts.text: Q.5 Can I apply for a K-3 or K-4 visa if I no longer wish to continue with my application for an immigrant visa?

texts.label: text
texts.orig: A K-3 or K-4 visa entitles the holder to reside in the United States only until he or she becomes eligible to apply for an immigrant visa. If you do not wish to pursue an application for an immigrant visa, you will not qualify for the K visa.
texts.text: A K-3 or K-4 visa entitles the holder to reside in the United States only until he or she becomes eligible to apply for an immigrant visa. If you do not wish to pursue an application for an immigrant visa, you will not qualify for the K visa.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: back to top
texts.text: back to top

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Q.6 Can I apply for a K-3 or K-4 visa while in the United States?
texts.text: Q.6 Can I apply for a K-3 or K-4 visa while in the United States?

texts.label: text
texts.orig: No. You are required to return to the county where you were married to apply for the visa. If the marriage ceremony took place in the United States, you are required to apply for the visa at the Embassy or Consulate in your country of permanent or last residence.
texts.text: No. You are required to return to the county where you were married to apply for the visa. If the marriage ceremony took place in the United States, you are required to apply for the visa at the Embassy or Consulate in your country of permanent or last residence.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: back to top
texts.text: back to top

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Q.7 If my child is issued a K-4 visa, what happens if he or she turns 21 before an immigrant visa is issued?
texts.text: Q.7 If my child is issued a K-4 visa, what happens if he or she turns 21 before an immigrant visa is issued?

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Holders of K-4 visas will be admitted for two years or until the day before their twenty-first birthday, whichever is shorter. The K-4 visa holder's status will expire if he or she turns 21.
texts.text: Holders of K-4 visas will be admitted for two years or until the day before their twenty-first birthday, whichever is shorter. The K-4 visa holder's status will expire if he or she turns 21.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: back to top
texts.text: back to top

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Q.8 If my child is issued a K-4 visa, what happens if he or she marries before the immigrant visa issued?
texts.text: Q.8 If my child is issued a K-4 visa, what happens if he or she marries before the immigrant visa issued?

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Holders of K-4 visas will be admitted for two years or until the day before their twenty-first birthday, whichever is shorter.  The K-4 visa holder's status will expire if he or she turns 21 or gets married.
texts.text: Holders of K-4 visas will be admitted for two years or until the day before their twenty-first birthday, whichever is shorter.  The K-4 visa holder's status will expire if he or she turns 21 or gets married.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Q.9 How does the holder of a K-3 or K-4 visa apply for the immigrant visa?
texts.text: Q.9 How does the holder of a K-3 or K-4 visa apply for the immigrant visa?

texts.label: text
texts.orig: If you are physically present in the United States you may apply for an adjustment of status with the USCIS. If this is your intention, you should state this fact in answer to Q.21 of form I-130. If the I-130 has already been filed and you advised the USCIS that you would apply for the visa abroad, your spouse or parent should notify the USCIS that you will apply for an adjustment of status.
texts.text: If you are physically present in the United States you may apply for an adjustment of status with the USCIS. If this is your intention, you should state this fact in answer to Q.21 of form I-130. If the I-130 has already been filed and you advised the USCIS that you would apply for the visa abroad, your spouse or parent should notify the USCIS that you will apply for an adjustment of status.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: If you will apply for the immigrant visa at a U.S. Embassy or Consulate named on the immigrant visa petition, form I-130, the approved petition will be forwarded to the National Visa Center in New Hampshire, which will send you the packet of forms you are required to complete in connection with your application for an immigrant visa.
texts.text: If you will apply for the immigrant visa at a U.S. Embassy or Consulate named on the immigrant visa petition, form I-130, the approved petition will be forwarded to the National Visa Center in New Hampshire, which will send you the packet of forms you are required to complete in connection with your application for an immigrant visa.

texts.text: Q.5 How many copies are needed?

texts.label: text
texts.orig: An original signed I-864 or I-864A and one complete set of original documents as described are required for each sponsored immigrant who is the beneficiary of an immediate relative petition (spouse, child under 21, parent), regardless of the fact that the family members will attend the visa interview together and travel to the United States. An original signed I-864 or I-864A and one complete set of original documents as described are required only for the principal sponsored immigrant who is beneficiary of a family or employment based petition; accompanying dependents are listed in Part 3 of the I-864 and Part 2 of the I-864A.
texts.text: An original signed I-864 or I-864A and one complete set of original documents as described are required for each sponsored immigrant who is the beneficiary of an immediate relative petition (spouse, child under 21, parent), regardless of the fact that the family members will attend the visa interview together and travel to the United States. An original signed I-864 or I-864A and one complete set of original documents as described are required only for the principal sponsored immigrant who is beneficiary of a family or employment based petition; accompanying dependents are listed in Part 3 of the I-864 and Part 2 of the I-864A.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Q.6 What about the accompanying dependents?
texts.text: Q.6 What about the accompanying dependents?

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Dependents of sponsored immigrants in the family or employment based preference categories who will attend the immigrant visa interview and travel to the U.S. with the principal applicant may furnish either a signed original or a photocopy of the I-864/I-864A, if he or she is named in Part 3 of the I-864 or Part 2 of the I-864A. Copies of supporting documents will not be required.
texts.text: Dependents of sponsored immigrants in the family or employment based preference categories who will attend the immigrant visa interview and travel to the U.S. with the principal applicant may furnish either a signed original or a photocopy of the I-864/I-864A, if he or she is named in Part 3 of the I-864 or Part 2 of the I-864A. Copies of supporting documents will not be required.

texts.orig: Q.7 What if the dependents are not accompanying the principal applicant?
texts.text: Q.7 What if the dependents are not accompanying the principal applicant?

texts.label: text
texts.orig: If the dependents will not accompany the principal applicant to the visa interview and/or will not travel to the U.S. with him or her, each dependent will require a signed original I-864/I864A and complete set of supporting documents.
texts.text: If the dependents will not accompany the principal applicant to the visa interview and/or will not travel to the U.S. with him or her, each dependent will require a signed original I-864/I864A and complete set of supporting documents.

texts.orig: Yes. The forms may be photocopied, but where an original signature is required, you must comply with that requirement.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Q.1 I filed the immigrant visa petition, but can I be a sponsor if I am currently unemployed/retired/student and I am not earning an income?
texts.text: Q.1 I filed the immigrant visa petition, but can I be a sponsor if I am currently unemployed/retired/student and I am not earning an income?

texts.label: text
texts.orig: As the petitioner, you are required, by law, to file an I-864 even if you do not earn enough income. If you do not earn enough income, you may add the value of your assets and/or income and assets of your household members, if they are willing. If this still does not meet the federal poverty guidelines, a joint sponsor will be required to file an I-864.
texts.text: As the petitioner, you are required, by law, to file an I-864 even if you do not earn enough income. If you do not earn enough income, you may add the value of your assets and/or income and assets of your household members, if they are willing. If this still does not meet the federal poverty guidelines, a joint sponsor will be required to file an I-864.

texts.orig: Q.2 I am on welfare; can I still sponsor my relative?
texts.text: Q.2 I am on welfare; can I still sponsor my relative?

texts.label: text
texts.orig: As the petitioner, you are required, by law, to file an I-864 even if you are currently not earning an income. The welfare benefits you receive can be taken into consideration if you are acting as a sponsor or joint sponsor
texts.text: As the petitioner, you are required, by law, to file an I-864 even if you are currently not earning an income. The welfare benefits you receive can be taken into consideration if you are acting as a sponsor or joint sponsor

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Q.4 Does the sponsor/joint sponsor´s obligation end with divorce or the death of the sponsor/joint sponsor?
texts.text: Q.4 Does the sponsor/joint sponsor´s obligation end with divorce or the death of the sponsor/joint sponsor?

texts.label: text
texts.orig: No, divorce does not nullify the I-864. If the sponsor/joint sponsor dies, the sponsor/joint sponsor's estate remains liable for any support or requests for repayment of benefit that arose before the support obligation ended.
texts.text: No, divorce does not nullify the I-864. If the sponsor/joint sponsor dies, the sponsor/joint sponsor's estate remains liable for any support or requests for repayment of benefit that arose before the support obligation ended.

texts.orig: back to top
texts.text: back to top

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Q.5 What if the sponsor dies before all of the family members of the sponsored immigrant have entered the United States?
texts.text: Q.5 What if the sponsor dies before all of the family members of the sponsored immigrant have entered the United States?

texts.label: text
texts.orig: If the sponsor dies after the principal sponsored immigrant has entered the United States, but before his or her family members have immigrated, a joint sponsor may file an I-864. Example: A parent files an immigrant visa petition on behalf of a daughter and her family. The daughter and children immigrate to the U.S., but the husband remains in the United Kingdom for 12 months. At the time he wishes to immigrate the sponsor would be required to file a new I-864. However if he had died, a joint sponsor could file an I-864.
texts.text: If the sponsor dies after the principal sponsored immigrant has entered the United States, but before his or her family members have immigrated, a joint sponsor may file an I-864. Example: A parent files an immigrant visa petition on behalf of a daughter and her family. The daughter and children immigrate to the U.S., but the husband remains in the United Kingdom for 12 months. At the time he wishes to immigrate the sponsor would be required to file a new I-864. However if he had died, a joint sponsor could file an I-864.

As the petitioner, I am required to file an I-864 for them. However, given that the I-864 filed on my behalf is still in force, can I do this?
texts.text: Q.6 I recently immigrated to the United States. I have filed an immigrant visa petition for my spouse/son or daughter in the family based second preference category. As the petitioner, I am required to file an I-864 for them. However, given that the I-864 filed on my behalf is still in force, can I do this?

texts.label: text
texts.orig: You may file an I-864. If your income does not equal or exceed the poverty level guide for your household size, you will require a joint sponsor
texts.text: You may file an I-864. If your income does not equal or exceed the poverty level guide for your household size, you will require a joint sponsor

texts.orig: Q.7 Is there a limit on the number of joint sponsors?
texts.text: Q.7 Is there a limit on the number of joint sponsors?

texts.label: text
texts.orig: No, there is no limit. However, each joint sponsor must meet the income requirement of the Federal poverty guidelines for your household size.
texts.text: No, there is no limit. However, each joint sponsor must meet the income requirement of the Federal poverty guidelines for your household size.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Yes. Income that is not subject to taxation, such as a housing allowance if you are a member of the clergy or military personnel may be counted. However, the onus will be on you to prove the nature and amount of any income on which you rely, but are not included as wages/salary or other taxable income.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: If your income is not sufficient, you may count your personal assets and those assets of the qualifying household members who have signed the I-864. If by using of these sources you meet the poverty level guidelines, you are fine; if not, you will require a joint sponsor.

texts.orig: Q.10 What type of assets can be used?
texts.text: Q.10 What type of assets can be used?

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Any type of assets can be used if they are readily convertible to cash within a year. Liquid assets, such as savings deposits, stocks, bonds and certificates of deposit are best because they would be the most accessible for the support of the sponsored immigrant(s). However, other assets, such as property, may also be acceptable if they can be sold within a year.

texts.text: Q.11 Some/all of these assets are outside the United States. Is this OK?

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Yes. However, the assets must be readily convertible to cash within 12 months and you must be able to demonstrate the ability to take the money or assets out of the country where they are located. Many countries have strict regulations that severely limit the amount of cash or liquid assets an individual may take or send abroad. If you are a resident of Lebanon, you should visit the Customs home page on this website for further information.

For bank accounts, bank statements for the most recent 12 months, or a letter from the bank stating the data the account was opened, a history of deposits and withdrawals for the past year and the current balance will be required.

texts.orig: Q.17 Do I just total up my assets and add it to my income?
texts.text: Q.17 Do I just total up my assets and add it to my income?

texts.label: text
texts.orig: No. To be counted, the cash value of your assets must be at least five times the difference between your income and the 125% of the poverty line for your household size.

texts.text: Q.1 I am filing an immigrant visa petition on behalf of my brother. However, I have limited financial resources and I cannot afford to sponsor his wife and children. Is this OK?

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Yes. However, it does mean that only the persons you are able to sponsor, which must include your brother as the principal applicant, would be eligible to immigrate to the United States at this time. You would still be required to file an I-864 for your brother's wife and children, but could file at a later date when your financial circumstances had improved back to top

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Q.2 What are the advantages of limiting the number of people I sponsor?
texts.text: Q.2 What are the advantages of limiting the number of people I sponsor?

texts.label: text
texts.orig: By limiting the number of persons you sponsor, you would reduce the household size and thereby face a lower minimum income requirement. You should note however, that when it comes to filing an I-864 on behalf of your brother's wife and children, your brother would still be counted in the total, as an alien whom you are still obligated to support.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Q.3 I am divorced and my child resides in my household part of the time and with my spouse the other. Is he or she counted as part of my household?
texts.text: Q.3 I am divorced and my child resides in my household part of the time and with my spouse the other. Is he or she counted as part of my household?

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Dependent children of a divorced couple are members of the parent's household, even if they live part of the time with the other parent. A parent always has a legal obligation to support his or her child.
texts.text: Dependent children of a divorced couple are members of the parent's household, even if they live part of the time with the other parent. A parent always has a legal obligation to support his or her child.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: However, my spouse claims my child as a dependent on his or her tax return.
texts.text: However, my spouse claims my child as a dependent on his or her tax return.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Although only one of the parents may be legally entitled to child as a dependent on his or her tax return, the child is considered as part of both parent's households for purposes of the I-864 unless a parent can show that he or she has been relieved of any legal obligation to support the child.
texts.text: Although only one of the parents may be legally entitled to child as a dependent on his or her tax return, the child is considered as part of both parent's households for purposes of the I-864 unless a parent can show that he or she has been relieved of any legal obligation to support the child.

However, sponsors residing outside the United States are not automatically disqualified from being a sponsor if they are able to show that they are temporarily resident outside the United States. Joint sponsors must be resident in the United States to qualify.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Q.1 How do you define "temporary" resident outside the United States?
texts.text: Q.1 How do you define "temporary" resident outside the United States?

texts.label: text
texts.orig: The sponsor must satisfy the consular officer that he/she has not given up his/her permanent residence in the United States to establish a residence abroad; i.e. he or she has maintained his/her principal residence in the United States with the intent to maintain that residence for the foreseeable future. Lawful Permanent Residents must further demonstrate that they have maintained their legal permanent residence status. The decision will be on a case-by-case basis. The following is a list of the types of employment, which is considered meeting the definition of "domiciled" in the United States, if the sponsor has been temporarily working outside the United States. The list also covers a sponsor who is the spouse or son/daughter of a person employed abroad in one of the listed professions.
texts.text: The sponsor must satisfy the consular officer that he/she has not given up his/her permanent residence in the United States to establish a residence abroad; i.e. he or she has maintained his/her principal residence in the United States with the intent to maintain that residence for the foreseeable future. Lawful Permanent Residents must further demonstrate that they have maintained their legal permanent residence status. The decision will be on a case-by-case basis. The following is a list of the types of employment, which is considered meeting the definition of "domiciled" in the United States, if the sponsor has been temporarily working outside the United States. The list also covers a sponsor who is the spouse or son/daughter of a person employed abroad in one of the listed professions.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: The list includes, but is not limited to employment by:
texts.text: The list includes, but is not limited to employment by:

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: · the U.S. government, including the U.S. Armed Forces;
texts.text: · the U.S. government, including the U.S. Armed Forces;

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: · an American Institution of research recognized as such by the Attorney General;
texts.text: · an American Institution of research recognized as such by the Attorney General;

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: · an American firm or corporation engaged in whole or in part in the development of foreign trade and commerce with the United States or a subsidiary thereof;
texts.text: · an American firm or corporation engaged in whole or in part in the development of foreign trade and commerce with the United States or a subsidiary thereof;

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: · by a public international organization in which the U.S. participates by treaty or status; and
texts.text: · by a public international organization in which the U.S. participates by treaty or status; and

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: · a person who is performing the ministerial or priestly functions of a religious denomination having a bona fide organization with the United States who is temporarily stationed abroad pursuant to that calling of is engaged solely as a missionary by a religious denomination or by an interdenominational mission organization having a bona fide organization within the United States and is stationed to that calling.
texts.text: · a person who is performing the ministerial or priestly functions of a religious denomination having a bona fide organization with the United States who is temporarily stationed abroad pursuant to that calling of is engaged solely as a missionary by a religious denomination or by an interdenominational mission organization having a bona fide organization within the United States and is stationed to that calling.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: There may be other instances where the sponsor is temporarily residing outside the United States, for example, he or she may be studying or teaching. As stated, the defining factor is whether or not the individual is able to show that his or her residence outside the United States is clearly of a temporary nature and that he or she did not give up his/her residence in the United States to establish a residence abroad.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Q.2 What if I have not maintained a residence in the United States?
texts.text: Q.2 What if I have not maintained a residence in the United States?

texts.label: text
texts.orig: If you are acting as a joint sponsor, you are required to show that you have maintained a residence in the United States. However, in cases where a sponsor may have abandoned his or her residence in the United States to live abroad, may have not lived there since a child, or in some cases, may never have resided there, he or she will not automatically be disqualified to act as a sponsor. In such cases, the question becomes do you intend to reestablish a residence in the United States. If this is indeed your intention and you can prove that you have or intend to re-establish U.S. residence, it may be possible for you to act as a sponsor.
texts.text: If you are acting as a joint sponsor, you are required to show that you have maintained a residence in the United States. However, in cases where a sponsor may have abandoned his or her residence in the United States to live abroad, may have not lived there since a child, or in some cases, may never have resided there, he or she will not automatically be disqualified to act as a sponsor. In such cases, the question becomes do you intend to reestablish a residence in the United States. If this is indeed your intention and you can prove that you have or intend to re-establish U.S. residence, it may be possible for you to act as a sponsor.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: You may meet this requirement by showing that you have taken or will take a credible combination of steps to make the U.S. your immediate principal place of residence. Such steps may include finding employment, locating a place to live, registering children in U.S. schools, etc. In addition, you should make arrangements to abandon your residence abroad; for example obtaining a valuation of your property from an estate agent.
texts.text: You may meet this requirement by showing that you have taken or will take a credible combination of steps to make the U.S. your immediate principal place of residence. Such steps may include finding employment, locating a place to live, registering children in U.S. schools, etc. In addition, you should make arrangements to abandon your residence abroad; for example obtaining a valuation of your property from an estate agent.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Q.3 As the sponsor, will I have to travel to the United States ahead of my relative to establish residence?
texts.text: Q.3 As the sponsor, will I have to travel to the United States ahead of my relative to establish residence?

texts.label: text
texts.orig: No. It will not be necessary for you to travel to the United States ahead of your spouse/children. However, you will be required to furnish evidence confirming the steps taken to re-establish your residence in the United States, e.g., a letter of employment, rental agreement, purchase of property, a letter from an estate agent in Lebanon showing the valuation of your property. Note: Your relative may not enter the United States to take up residence prior to your return to the United States. He or she may travel with you, or follow to join you at a later date

texts.label: text
texts.orig: In order to file an I-864, the sponsor must be a "resident" of the United States as described above. If you do not maintain a residence in the United States and have no intention of reestablishing a residence, there, I regret it will not be possible for you to act as sponsor. If you cannot act as a sponsor, it will not be possible for your relative to qualify for immigration on the basis of an immigrant visa petition filed by yourself.

texts.text: FAQ-Affidavit Form I-864 - Tax Returns

texts.label: text
texts.orig: U.S. law requires that the sponsor and joint sponsor (if there is one) submit one year's tax returns, current as of the date of execution of the I-864. American citizens and LPRs who are working abroad are required by IRS to file a return, even if most or all of their overseas income is excluded from U.S. taxes; a social security number is required to file a tax return. Information on general filing requirements, including information on filing tax returns retroactively, you should contact the Internal Revenue Service (IRS) on 020 7894-0477, or visit their homepage on this website. Further information is available at "the Digital Daily" at http://www.irs.gov. If your question concerns a social security number, you should contact the Federal Benefits Unit on 020 7499 9000 between 8.30 am and 1.00 pm, Monday through Friday, or visit their homepage on this website for further information.

texts.orig: Q.2 What should I do if I move to another country after I have registered my profile on ustraveldocs.com and did not apply yet for my visa, or if I want to submit a new visa application in another country than my previous application?
texts.text: Q.2 What should I do if I move to another country after I have registered my profile on ustraveldocs.com and did not apply yet for my visa, or if I want to submit a new visa application in another country than my previous application?

texts.label: text
texts.orig: You do not need to create another profile if it is also serviced by CGI. You can simply contact us through the Contact Us section on this website  and share your passport number, UID or email address so we can retrieve and update your profile with the new country where you plan to apply for your US Visa. If you are applying in a country that is not covered by CGI, you will be invited to create a new profile. As a reminder, MRV fee receipts paid in one country are non-transferable to the other country.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Q.1 Will I be eligible to work on entering the United States on an immigrant visa?
texts.text: Q.1 Will I be eligible to work on entering the United States on an immigrant visa?

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Upon entering the United States on an immigrant visa, you will require no further authorization from the United States Citizenship and Immigration Services (USCIS) in order to take up employment.
texts.text: Upon entering the United States on an immigrant visa, you will require no further authorization from the United States Citizenship and Immigration Services (USCIS) in order to take up employment.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: back to top
texts.text: back to top

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Q.2 How do I get a Social Security number?
texts.text: Q.2 How do I get a Social Security number?

texts.label: text
texts.orig: By law, each immigrant or refugee admitted to the United States must obtain a Social Security number. Social Security numbers are required to work in the U.S., to open a bank account, to pay taxes, and for many other purposes. An application for a social security number should be made to the local Social Security Office in the area where the immigrant will reside after their arrival in the United States. For further information, please visit their website at http://www.ssa.gov/

Social Security numbers are required to work in the U.S., to open a bank account, to pay taxes, and for many other purposes. An application for a social security number should be made to the local Social Security Office in the area where the immigrant will reside after their arrival in the United States. For further information, please visit their website at http://www.ssa.gov/

texts.text: back to top

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Q.3 How do I become an American citizen?
texts.text: Q.3 How do I become an American citizen?

texts.label: text
texts.orig: An immigrant can become an American citizen by naturalization by living in the United States for a specified period, usually five years (three years if married to a citizen) and passing a naturalization examination. However, there is no requirement that an immigrant become a citizen and s/he is free to live in the United States as long as s/he wishes regardless of his citizenship, so long as s/he abides by the laws of the land, which are applicable to citizens and aliens alike.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Q.4 Do you have information on the education system?
texts.text: Q.4 Do you have information on the education system?

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Education is compulsory and free for children between the ages of 6 and 16 (18 in some states). Kindergartens are usually available and free of charge. Children will ordinarily be accepted for immediate enrollment in the local school system of the community in which an immigrant family settles. Private schools, both day and boarding, which are the equivalent of English preparatory and public schools, are available in many larger communities but are expensive. There are many universities, some private and some government-supported.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Q.5 How much money can I bring into the United States?
texts.text: Q.5 How much money can I bring into the United States?

texts.label: text
texts.orig: There is no limit on the amount of money, which may be taken in or out of the United States. However, any amount in excess of $10,000 in currency, travelers checks or negotiable instruments, must be declared to the United States Customs at the time of arrival in or departure from the United States.  http://www.cbp.gov/
